creator: jeff150

content:
I have found that my service provider (charter.net) automatically categorizes certain messages as Spam, and when that has happened they seem to be downloaded automatically into the Junk folder.

If gandi.net offers a web interface to their mail, you might check your Spam folder there, and see if they're doing something similar.

If so, I think you'll find that it is not Thunderbird Junk processing, but simply your provider saying "this message will be in the Junk folder when it is downloaded".
creator: walt.f

content: @wait.f: Can you explain what your mean by the "service provider ... automatically categorizes certain messages as Spam"? Categorizes how? I don't mean how it decides; I mean how it indicates to the client. Does it add a header that Thunderbird obeys? Or something else. It is presumably up to Thunderbird where it puts messages. (BTW, it isn't "downloading" messages into the Junk folder; this is IMAP so the folders are all on the server. Something (I assume Thunderbird) is moving messages from the inbox into Junk.) I take your point about using a different client, whether the provider's web client or some other. If I see a message in the inbox there, but then it appears in Junk when I access the account via Thunderbird, that will demonstrate that it really is Thunderbird doing this.
creator: jeff150

content:
> Categorizes how? I don't mean how it decides; I mean how it indicates to the client.

It doesn't indicate to the client. It just puts it in the Junk folder.

You will know this because the message will not have Thunderbird's junk icon.
creator: wsmwk

content:
@jeff150: For one recent message I can see a header "X-Chtr-Junkmail: 1" but that remains in the message even after I tell Charter/Spectrum that the message is Not Spam via their webmail interface.

Telling Charter/Spectrum that the message was Not Spam moved it from the Spam folder to Inbox in their webmail interface, and moved it from Junk to Inbox in Thunderbird. So it appears that as @Wayne Mery indicated it's simply that Charter/Spectrum has delivered it from their Spam folder to Thunderbird's Junk Mail folder automatically. And when I marked it as Not Spam in the webmail interface, the next time Thunderbird contacted the iMap server to query Inbox the message automatically appeared there.
creator: walt.f

This happened to me today! A shocker! I looked at some 'fixes' some users had used (simple stuff like turning on show all, but none of those worked.

You asked for:

Version: 128.1esr (I updated it just after I lost the emails in my inbox -- about 600 of them, some VERY important as they deal with businesses -- they go back several years. I had hoped that updating might restore those emails lost. Didn't. I also tried rebooting the program, and rebooting my desktop computer. Somehow it seems it lost the address where they were stored during compacting -- or in compacting, it deleted the wrong info and now they cannot be found. Obviously, I don't know.)

User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; rv:128.0) Gecko/20100101 Thunderbird/128.5.1

Hope this helps!

My version doesn't ask IF I want to compact the inbox, it just does it and pauses the program and tells me at the bottom that it is compacting. Oddly, it the list of emails disappears while it processes and returns when finished and then the program starts to work again.

content:
Globálna databáza je indexovací systém umožňujúcí Thunderbirdu vyhľadávať v zprávach. Znovuvytvorenie globálnej databázy preindexuje správy a vizitky z adresára. (Správy z konferencií nie sú indexované.)

Postup znovuvytvorenia globálnej databázy: - Ukončite Thunderbird. - Vyhľadajte vo svojom profile Thunderbirdu súbor global-messages-db.sqlite - Vymažte tento súbor. - Spustite Thunderbird. Automaticky sa začne proces vytvárania indexu. V závislosti na počte správ môže indexácia trvať dosť dlhý čas (cca 5 minút). Počas indexácie môžete Thunderbird používat, iba bude znížený jeho výkon a vyhľadávania prinesú iba čiastočné výsledky, alebo dokonca žiadne. Proces indexácie môžete sledovať v Správcovi aktivít (ponuka Nástroje > Správca činnosti).

content: That letter is important for some microsoft users as some email clients (NOT Thunderbird) didn't support Oauth2 at the time of the announcement and are working to correct that. There is no change for Thunderbird, as TB is already designed to support the new MS direction - which is basically to use their servers (outlook.office365.com and smtp.office365.com and use Oauth2. If you have that setting, you're good.

content:
Thanks to Leigh's tip, I was able to get back online. Here's what I did: I went to Tools/Account Settings. At the bottom of the list of accounts and sub-folders is the Account Actions button. I clicked the button and selected the Add Mail Account option. I basically followed the prompts, using my existing @cox.net account name and password. Thunderbird offered to search for a compatible server and came back with the Yahoo IMAP server. I just followed the prompts. I went ahead and entered my password again when the weird Yahoo sign in screen popped up. After Thunderbird finished setting up the account it automatically downloaded all the messages from the server. The new IMAP account showed up in the list below the old POP account of the same name. (See Leigh's screen shots for an example.) All my old POP account folders are still there and intact. I can move their contents over to the IMAP account folders via select-all and drag operations.

I hope this helps.
